trans-unit.source: Azure virtual machine backup - Troubleshooting | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure virtual machine backup - Troubleshooting | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Find information to troubleshoot backup and restore of Azure virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Find information to troubleshoot backup and restore of Azure virtual machine

trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting errors

trans-unit.source: You can troubleshoot errors encountered while using Azure Backup with information listed in the table below.
trans-unit.target: You can troubleshoot errors encountered while using Azure Backup with information listed in the table below.

trans-unit.target: This happens when there is too much data to be copied.

trans-unit.source: This error is thrown if there is a problem with the VM Agent or network access to the Azure infrastructure is blocked in some way. <html></html><html></html>Learn about <link><linkText>debugging VM Agent issues</linkText><title></title></link> <html></html>Learn about <link><linkText>debugging networking issues</linkText><title></title></link> <html></html><html></html>If the VM agent is not causing any issues, then restart the VM. At times an incorrect VM state can cause issues and restarting the VM resets this "bad state"
trans-unit.target: This error is thrown if there is a problem with the VM Agent or network access to the Azure infrastructure is blocked in some way. <html></html><html></html>Learn about <link><linkText>debugging VM Agent issues</linkText><title></title></link> <html></html>Learn about <link><linkText>debugging networking issues</linkText><title></title></link> <html></html><html></html>If the VM agent is not causing any issues, then restart the VM. At times an incorrect VM state can cause issues and restarting the VM resets this "bad state"

trans-unit.source: Backup
trans-unit.target: Backup

trans-unit.source: Backup failed with an internal error - Please retry the operation in a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: Backup failed with an internal error - Please retry the operation in a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: If the problem persists, contact Microsoft Support
trans-unit.target: If the problem persists, contact Microsoft Support

trans-unit.source: You can get this error for 2 reasons: <html></html><html></html> There is too much data to be copied. <html></html>The original VM has been deleted and therefore backup cannot be taken. In order to keep the backup data for a deleted VM but stop the backup errors, Unprotect the VM and choose the option to keep the data. This will stop the backup schedule and also the recurring error messages.
trans-unit.target: You can get this error for 2 reasons: <html></html><html></html> There is too much data to be copied. <html></html>The original VM has been deleted and therefore backup cannot be taken. In order to keep the backup data for a deleted VM but stop the backup errors, Unprotect the VM and choose the option to keep the data. This will stop the backup schedule and also the recurring error messages.

trans-unit.target: Extension installation failed with the error "COM+ was unable to talk to the Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator

trans-unit.source: This usually means that the COM+ service is not running.
trans-unit.target: This usually means that the COM+ service is not running.

trans-unit.source: Contact Microsoft support for help on fixing this issue.
trans-unit.target: Contact Microsoft support for help on fixing this issue.

trans-unit.target: Snapshot operation failed with the VSS operation error "This drive is locked by BitLocker Drive Encryption.

trans-unit.source: You must unlock this drive from Control Panel.
trans-unit.target: You must unlock this drive from Control Panel.

trans-unit.source: Turn off BitLocker for all drives on the VM and observe if the VSS issue is resolved
trans-unit.target: Turn off BitLocker for all drives on the VM and observe if the VSS issue is resolved

trans-unit.source: This happens when the primary VM is deleted but the backup policy continues to look for a VM to perform backup. To fix this error: <html></html><html></html>Recreate the virtual machine with the same name and same resource group name [cloud service name], <html></html>(OR) <html></html> Disable protection for this VM so that backup jobs will not be created <html></html>
trans-unit.target: This happens when the primary VM is deleted but the backup policy continues to look for a VM to perform backup. To fix this error: <html></html><html></html>Recreate the virtual machine with the same name and same resource group name [cloud service name], <html></html>(OR) <html></html> Disable protection for this VM so that backup jobs will not be created <html></html>

trans-unit.source: Restore failed with Cloud Internal error
trans-unit.target: Restore failed with Cloud Internal error

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Cloud service to which you are trying to restore is configured with DNS settings. You can check <html></html>$deployment = Get-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "ServiceName" -Slot "Production" Get-AzureDns -DnsSettings $deployment.DnsSettings<html></html>If there is Address configured, this means that DNS settings are configured.<html></html> <html></html>Cloud service to which to you are trying to restore is configured with ReservedIP and existing VMs in cloud service are in stopped state.<html></html>You can check a cloud service has reserved IP by using following powershell cmdlets:<html></html>$deployment = Get-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "servicename" -Slot "Production" $dep.ReservedIPName<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Cloud service to which you are trying to restore is configured with DNS settings. You can check <html></html>$deployment = Get-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "ServiceName" -Slot "Production" Get-AzureDns -DnsSettings $deployment.DnsSettings<html></html>If there is Address configured, this means that DNS settings are configured.<html></html> <html></html>Cloud service to which to you are trying to restore is configured with ReservedIP and existing VMs in cloud service are in stopped state.<html></html>You can check a cloud service has reserved IP by using following powershell cmdlets:<html></html>$deployment = Get-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "servicename" -Slot "Production" $dep.ReservedIPName<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Restore
trans-unit.target: Restore

trans-unit.source: The selected DNS name is already taken - Please specify a different DNS name and try again.
trans-unit.target: The selected DNS name is already taken - Please specify a different DNS name and try again.

trans-unit.source: The DNS name here refers to the cloud service name (usually ending with .cloudapp.net). This needs to be unique. If you encounter this error, you need to choose a different VM name during restore. <html></html><html></html> Note that this error is shown only to users of the Azure portal. The restore operation through PowerShell will succeed because it only restores the disks and doesn't create the VM. The error will be faced when the VM is explicitly created by you after the disk restore operation.
trans-unit.target: The DNS name here refers to the cloud service name (usually ending with .cloudapp.net). This needs to be unique. If you encounter this error, you need to choose a different VM name during restore. <html></html><html></html> Note that this error is shown only to users of the Azure portal. The restore operation through PowerShell will succeed because it only restores the disks and doesn't create the VM. The error will be faced when the VM is explicitly created by you after the disk restore operation.

trans-unit.source: VM Agent
trans-unit.target: VM Agent

trans-unit.source: Setting up the VM Agent
trans-unit.target: Setting up the VM Agent

trans-unit.source: Typically, the VM Agent is already present in VMs that are created from the Azure gallery.
trans-unit.target: Typically, the VM Agent is already present in VMs that are created from the Azure gallery.

trans-unit.source: However, virtual machines that are migrated from on-premises datacenters would not have the VM Agent installed.
trans-unit.target: However, virtual machines that are migrated from on-premises datacenters would not have the VM Agent installed.

trans-unit.source: For such VMs, the VM Agent needs to be installed explicitly.
trans-unit.target: For such VMs, the VM Agent needs to be installed explicitly.

trans-unit.source: Read more about <link><linkText>installing the VM agent on an existing VM</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Read more about <link><linkText>installing the VM agent on an existing VM</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For Windows VMs:
trans-unit.target: For Windows VMs:

trans-unit.source: Download and install the <link><linkText>agent MSI</linkText><title></title></link>. You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.
trans-unit.target: Download and install the <link><linkText>agent MSI</linkText><title></title></link>. You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Update the VM property</linkText><title></title></link> to indicate that the agent is installed.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Update the VM property</linkText><title></title></link> to indicate that the agent is installed.

trans-unit.source: Updating the VM Agent
trans-unit.target: Updating the VM Agent

trans-unit.source: Updating the VM Agent is as simple as reinstalling the <link><linkText>VM Agent binaries</linkText><title></title></link>. However, you need to ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM Agent is being updated.
trans-unit.target: Updating the VM Agent is as simple as reinstalling the <link><linkText>VM Agent binaries</linkText><title></title></link>. However, you need to ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM Agent is being updated.

trans-unit.source: Validating VM Agent installation
trans-unit.target: Validating VM Agent installation

trans-unit.source: How to check for the VM Agent version on Windows VMs:
trans-unit.target: How to check for the VM Agent version on Windows VMs:

trans-unit.source: Log on to the Azure virtual machine and navigate to the folder C:\WindowsAzure\Packages.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the Azure virtual machine and navigate to the folder C:\WindowsAzure\Packages.

trans-unit.source: You should find the WaAppAgent.exe file present.
trans-unit.target: You should find the WaAppAgent.exe file present.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the file, go to Properties, and then select the Details tab.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the file, go to Properties, and then select the Details tab.

trans-unit.source: The Product Version field should be 2.6.1198.718 or higher
trans-unit.target: The Product Version field should be 2.6.1198.718 or higher

trans-unit.source: Networking
trans-unit.target: Networking

trans-unit.source: Like all extensions, Backup extension need access to the public internet to work.
trans-unit.target: Like all extensions, Backup extension need access to the public internet to work.

trans-unit.source: Not having access to the public internet can manifest itself in a variety of of ways:
trans-unit.target: Not having access to the public internet can manifest itself in a variety of of ways:

trans-unit.source: The extension installation can fail
trans-unit.target: The extension installation can fail

trans-unit.source: The backup operations (like disk snapshot) can fail
trans-unit.target: The backup operations (like disk snapshot) can fail

trans-unit.source: Displaying the status of the backup operation can fail
trans-unit.target: Displaying the status of the backup operation can fail

trans-unit.source: The need for resolving public internet addresses has been articulated <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The need for resolving public internet addresses has been articulated <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You will need to check the DNS configurations for the VNET and ensure that the Azure URIs can be resolved.
trans-unit.target: You will need to check the DNS configurations for the VNET and ensure that the Azure URIs can be resolved.

trans-unit.source: Once the name resolution is done correctly, access to the Azure IPs also needs to be provided.
trans-unit.target: Once the name resolution is done correctly, access to the Azure IPs also needs to be provided.

trans-unit.source: To unblock access to the Azure infrastructure, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To unblock access to the Azure infrastructure, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Get the list of <link><linkText>Azure datacenter IPs</linkText><title></title></link> to be whitelisted.
trans-unit.target: Get the list of <link><linkText>Azure datacenter IPs</linkText><title></title></link> to be whitelisted.

trans-unit.source: Unblock the IPs using the <link><linkText>New-NetRoute</linkText><title></title></link> commandlet.
trans-unit.target: Unblock the IPs using the <link><linkText>New-NetRoute</linkText><title></title></link> commandlet.

trans-unit.source: Run this commandlet within the Azure VM, in an elevated PowerShell window (run as Administrator).
trans-unit.target: Run this commandlet within the Azure VM, in an elevated PowerShell window (run as Administrator).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
